docs.title: Highlights
docs.text:
• Installs and manages C/C++ toolchains.
  • Supports Linux, and nothing else (yet).

docs.title: Getting started
docs.text:
To help you get started with cv, we'll cover the following topics:

  • Installation
  • First steps

docs.title: First steps with cv
docs.text:
After installing cv, you can check that cv is available by running the cv command:

$ cv
A fast, minimal C/C++ toolchain manager.

Usage: cv [OPTIONS] <COMMAND>

...
You should see a help message with available commands and options.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text: Now that you have cv installed correctly, jump to the guides to learn to use cv.

docs.title: GitHub Releases
docs.text: cv release artifacts are available on GitHub Releases. Each release contains binaries for all supported platforms.

docs.title: Working on projects
docs.text: cv supports managing C/C++ projects, which define their dependencies in a cvproject.toml file.

docs.title: Creating a new project
docs.text:
You can create a new project using the cv init command:

mkdir my_project
cd my_project
cv init

This will create a project with default settings, including the following files:

my_project/
├── .gitignore
├── README.md
├── src/main.c
└── cvproject.toml

docs.title: Using tools
docs.text: cv has support for easily invoking various tools.

docs.title: Running tools
docs.text:
The cvx command invokes a tool without installing it.

For example, to run make:

cvx make

Note

This is exactly equivalent to:

cv tool run make

cvx is provided as an alias for convenience.

docs.title: Getting started
docs.text:
To install the latest version of zig, run:

cv zig install

The command downloads the latest official release from ziglang.org. cv installs a versioned distribution to ~/.local/share/cv/zig/<version>. To install zig executables to ~/.local/bin, include the --default flag:

cv zig install --default

docs.title: Viewing Zig installations
docs.text:
To view available and installed versions of zig, run:

cv zig list
